title: A planned fire threatened lives of two California sequoias; now they are sprouting new life
description: A pair of giant sequoias were damaged in a prescribed burn last fall at Calaveras Big Trees State Park—and when they were discovered months later, it was unknown whether one of them would survive.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Chemists make breakthrough in drug discovery chemistry: Two methods to replace carbon with a nitrogen atom in a molecule
description: For years, if you asked the people working to create new pharmaceutical drugs what they wished for, at the top of their lists would be a way to easily replace a carbon atom with a nitrogen atom in a molecule.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Does banning books really help kids? A childhood education expert weighs in
description: When Jaci Urbani taught early learners at the Pennsylvania School for the Deaf, one of the books she read to them was "Charlotte's Web," by E.B. White, a children's novel about a pig destined for slaughter and his friendship with the barn spider who saves him.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Analysts who disclose company forecasts for a wide range of financial outcomes have better performance, finds study
description: If you are in search of accurate forecasts on a company's earnings and future stock prices, you could do better turning to analysts who have recently disclosed a wide range of forecasts for the same company—not only earnings and price targets, but also cash flow, dividends, book value, capital expenditure, gross margin, operating income, pre-tax income forecasts and so on, according to a new paper by Peter Pope of Bocconi's Department of Accounting and recent Bocconi Ph.D. graduate Tong Wang, now at Barclays plc in London.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Invasive 'giant' reptile lurks under Georgia porch, officials say: Here's why it is dangerous
description: A Georgia homeowner was in for a shock when she found a 3-foot reptile living under her house, wildlife officials say.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: NASA's Lucy spacecraft swoops past first of 10 asteroids on long journey to Jupiter
description: NASA's Lucy spacecraft on Wednesday encountered the first of 10 asteroids on its long journey to Jupiter.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Four dead as Tropical Storm Pilar dumps heavy rains on C. America
description: Tropical Storm Pilar loomed ominously off the Pacific Coast of Central America on Wednesday, provoking heavy rains that washed away crops and displaced hundreds of people as the death toll rose to four.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists develop a legged small celestial body landing mechanism for landing simulation and experimental test
description: Landing stably is a precondition for exploring a small celestial body in situ. The surface of a small celestial body frequently has weak gravity and is irregular, and the surface environment is unknown and uncertain. The landing mechanism tends to rebound and turn over, and the landing stability time is long. However, while most landing performance research has focused on lunar landing, there are differences between the surfaces of the moon and Mars.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Reactant enrichment of nanoreactors boosts hydrogenation performance
description: Hollow-structured supported metal catalysts (i.e. nanoreactor catalysts) with encapsulated active sites and well-defined shells provide an ideal place for multicomponents to react or transform cooperatively in an orderly manner, and efficiently have been recognized as one of the most popular catalyst candidates.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Research team discovers lactic acid bacteria strains with high virus resistance from kimchi
description: From kimchi fermented at low temperatures for a long period of time, researchers at the World Institute of Kimchi have isolated lactic acid bacteria (LAB) strains with high levels of resistance to phages. They have also identified the defense mechanism of the LAB strains against phages, viruses that infect and replicate within bacteria.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: What happens when cats get fat? Scientists weigh in
description: Cat owners want Kitty to be happy, but providing an abundance of food and snacks can have unintended consequences. Feline obesity is on the rise, impacting the health, longevity, and well-being of cats. A new study from the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign looks at what happens in the digestive system and gut microbiota when cats eat too much.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Processor made for AI speeds up genome assembly
description: A hardware accelerator initially developed for artificial intelligence operations successfully speeds up the alignment of protein and DNA molecules, making the process up to 10 times faster than state-of-the-art methods.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How the relationship between the land and atmosphere facilitated China's extreme weather in summer 2022
description: Extreme weather and climate events, such as droughts, heat waves, and rainstorms, pose serious threats to human health, agricultural production, and energy supplies. These events often occur at the same time, and such "compound extreme events" can cause far more damage than any one single event.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Rethinking quality: Experts challenge the harmful influence of global university rankings
description: An Independent Expert Group (IEG) convened by the United Nations University's International Institute for Global Health (UNU IIGH) has released a strong statement criticizing the wide and uncritical use of global university rankings.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Optimizing office environments for work efficiency and worker health
description: The quality of the office environment significantly affects work efficiency and worker health. Therefore, creating and maintaining an optimal built environment in the office can be a key step in maximizing a company's economic growth.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A mathematical model for studying methane hydrate distribution in the Nankai Trough
description: Methane hydrate is a naturally occurring ice-like crystalline solid that forms when methane and water are subjected to geological high-pressure and low-temperature conditions. It is often found trapped in continental margin sediments and permafrost.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The secret to enhancing consumer valuation and addressing the climate crisis: Introduce circular take-back programs
description: Researchers from Boston University published a Journal of Marketing study showing that tapping into consumers' sense of ownership prompts them to place a higher value on products from a circular economy.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Q&A: Student examines how the pandemic affected how we pursued our goals
description: COVID-19 upended lives worldwide, impacting hopes and dreams as well as disrupting goals.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Ozone hole is about average size, despite undersea volcano eruption that was expected to worsen it
description: With last year's undersea volcano injecting massive amounts of water high into the atmosphere, scientists were bracing for a big Antarctica ozone hole this fall. But it didn't happen.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Investigating resiliency and vulnerability of global supply chains during the COVID-19 pandemic
description: It's no secret that the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted supply chains across the globe. In the United States, it often seemed like stores couldn't keep certain items in stock. Now, new research is diving more deeply into the resiliency and vulnerability of global supply chains during the COVID-19 pandemic.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: OSIRIS-REx flies on as OSIRIS-APEX to explore its second asteroid
description: After seven years in space and over 4 billion miles traveled, NASA's OSIRIS-REx mission successfully collected and delivered the first U.S. sample from a near-Earth asteroid. Yet, after all this time and travel, the spacecraft will not retire.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Intraspecific microdiversity and ecological drivers of lactic acid bacteria in naturally fermented milk ecosystem
description: Traditional fermented milks are produced by the inoculating technique, which selects well-adapted microorganisms that have been passed on through generations. Few reports have used naturally fermented milks as model ecosystems to investigate the mechanism of formation of intra-species microbial diversity.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Flight-collected data links methane plumes to tundra fires in western Alaska
description: In Alaska's largest river delta, tundra that has been scorched by wildfire, is still emitting more methane than the rest of the landscape long after the flames died, scientists have found. The potent greenhouse gas can originate from decomposing carbon stored in permafrost for thousands of years. Its release could accelerate climate warming and lead to more frequent wildfires in the tundra, where blazes have been historically rare.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Demonic obsession: A different look at mental health in the medieval period
description: Demons today are characterized in horror movies like "The Ring," "The Conjuring," and "The Exorcist" as paranormal entities—supernaturally powerful beings, with little relevance in reality. But in the medieval period, demons were ever-present. Specifically in medieval Europe, demons bedeviled communities, shocked religious leaders, and puzzled doctors.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Is the jet stream changing?
description: Heavy precipitation, wind storms, heat waves—when severe weather events such as these occur they are frequently attributed to a wavy jet stream. The jet stream is a powerful air current in the upper troposphere that balances the pressure gradient and Coriolis forces. It is still not known whether the jet stream is really undergoing changes at decadal timescales and, if so, to what extent.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How Webb telescope development led to improved simulation software
description: The James Webb Space Telescope truly explores the unknown, displaying stunning images of previously unseen corners of the universe only possible because of the telescope's 21-foot segmented mirror that unfurled and assembled itself in space.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Spatiotemporal mode-locking and dissipative solitons in multimode fiber lasers
description: The birth of spatiotemporal mode-locking (STML) can date back to the report of Wright and colleagues in 2017. Following this breakthrough, research on STML has thrived. However, our comprehension and control of spatiotemporal dissipative solitons (STDSs) and STML in multi-mode fiber (MMF) lasers are not as mature as those in single-mode fiber lasers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 'Peace speech' in the media characterizes a country's peaceful culture, suggests new study
description: By analyzing the frequency of certain words within mainstream news media from any country, a machine learning algorithm can produce a quantitative "peace index" that captures the level of peace within that country, according to a study published in the open-access journal PLOS ONE  by Larry Liebovitch and Peter T. Coleman of Columbia University, US, and colleagues.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Game performance of immigrant NBA players might suffer in context of far-right political support
description: During the 2020–2021 season of the National Basketball Association (NBA), which took place during Donald Trump's failed bid at re-election, immigrant players for teams in regions with stronger far-right political sentiments were more likely to make game errors—highlighting the possible detrimental effects of such views on immigrant workplace performance.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Giant dinosaur carcasses might have been important food sources for Jurassic predators
description: Carnivorous dinosaurs might have evolved to take advantage of giant carcasses, according to a study published November 1, 2023 in the open-access journal PLOS ONE by Cameron Pahl and Luis Ruedas of Portland State University, Oregon and colleagues.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Storm Ciaran triggers weather alert in northwestern Europe
description: Much of northwestern Europe went on high alert Wednesday as a storm dubbed Ciaran threatened to bring gale-force winds and extreme rainfall to the region.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Summer Science Program spent $2 million last year serving 204 students. Then, they got a $200M gift.
description: It's the kind of problem nonprofit leaders dream about: What do you do when you get an unexpectedly large donation?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study: Online conspiracy communities are more resilient to deplatforming
description: Social media can incubate communities that are so resilient that even banning them from the platform cannot destroy them. Michele Starnini and colleagues studied two online communities on the social media site Reddit: the far-right conspiracy theory subreddit "GreatAwakening," which was banned in 2018, and the hate-speech subreddit "FatPeopleHate," banned in 2015. Both communities decided among themselves to move to Voat, an unmoderated Reddit clone designed to serve those banned by Reddit.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New telescopes to study the aftermath of the Big Bang
description: Astronomers are currently pushing the frontiers of astronomy. At this very moment, observatories like the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) are visualizing the earliest stars and galaxies in the universe, which formed during a period known as the "Cosmic Dark Ages." This period was previously inaccessible to telescopes because the universe was permeated by clouds of neutral hydrogen.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists shoot first true-to-life 3D image of the thick filament of mammalian heart muscle
description: Atrial fibrillation, heart failure and stroke—hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can lead to many serious health conditions and is a major cause of sudden cardiac death in people younger than 35.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists use supercomputers to make optical tweezers safer for living cells
description: Optical tweezers manipulate tiny things like cells and nanoparticles using lasers. While they might sound like tractor beams from science fiction, the fact is their development garnered scientists a Nobel Prize in 2018.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Can there be double gravitational lenses?
description: If you, like me, have used telescopes to gaze out at the wonders of the universe, then you too may have been a little captivated by the topic of gravitational lensing. Think about it: how cool is it that the very universe we are trying to explore is actually providing us with telescopes to probe the darkest corners of space and time?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Did Betelgeuse consume a smaller star?
description: What's going on with Betelgeuse? In recent years it's generated a lot of headlines as its luminosity has shifted dramatically several times. The red supergiant brightened by almost 50% earlier this year, triggering speculation that it may go supernova.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Three planets around this sun-like star are doomed
description: According to new research we can start writing the eulogy for four exoplanets around a sun-like star about 57 light years away. But there's no hurry; we have about 1 billion years before the star becomes a red giant and starts to consume them.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Satellites make up to 80,000 flashing glints per hour. It's a big problem for astronomers
description: Large-scale sky surveys are set to revolutionize astronomy. Observatories such as Vera Rubin and others will allow astronomers to observe how the sky changes on the scale of days, not weeks or months. They will be able to capture transient events such as supernovae in their earliest stages and will discover near-Earth asteroids we have missed in the past. At the same time, the rise of satellite constellations such as Starlink threatens to overwhelm these surveys with light pollution and could threaten their ability to succeed.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Vera Rubin Observatory could find up to 70 interstellar objects a year
description: Astronomers have discovered two known interstellar objects (ISO), 'Oumuamua and 21/Borisov. But there could be thousands of these objects passing through the solar system at any time. According to a new paper, the upcoming Vera Rubin Telescope will be a fantastic interstellar object hunter, and could possibly find up to 70 objects a year coming from other star systems.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Dam removals, restoration project on Klamath River expected to help salmon, researchers conclude
description: The world's largest dam removal and restoration project currently underway on the Klamath River in Oregon and California will aid salmon populations that have been devastated by disease and other factors. However, it will not fully alleviate challenges faced by the species, a team of researchers conclude in a paper just published in Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Crypto study finds high risk doesn't equal reward
description: A study of more than 4,000 cryptocurrencies between 2015 to 2022 has found that high-risk cryptocurrencies generally underperform their low-risk counterparts.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Long presumed to have no heads at all, starfish may be nothing but
description: For centuries, naturalists have puzzled over what might constitute the head of a sea star, commonly called a "starfish." When looking at a worm, or a fish, it's clear which end is the head and which is the tail. But with their five identical arms—any of which can take the lead in propelling sea stars across the seabed—it's been anybody's guess how to determine the front end of the organism from the back. This unusual body plan has led many to conclude that sea stars perhaps don't have a head at all.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Massive anomaly within Earth's mantle may be remnant of collision that formed moon
description: An interdisciplinary international research team has recently discovered that a massive anomaly deep within the Earth's interior may be a remnant of the collision about 4.5 billion years ago that formed the moon.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New analysis of ancient fish may explain how shoulder evolved
description: A new analysis of the bones and muscles in ancient fish gives new clues about how the shoulder evolved in animals—including us.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How to improve your communication with someone with a speech impairment
description: October marked alternative and augmentative communication (AAC) awareness month. AAC includes all means of communication that a person may use besides talking. Low-tech methods include means of interaction like hand gestures, facial movements, or pointing, while more high-tech tools might include a speech generating device accessed through pointing or a joystick, eye-tracking, or even a brain-computer interface.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Storms or sea-level rise—what really causes beach erosion?
description: Beaches are dynamic. They change from week to week and month to month. Have you ever wondered what causes these changes? Or how beaches might fare as sea levels rise and if storms increase in frequency and severity?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Young female voters were the key to defeating populists in Poland: A blueprint to reverse democracy's decline
description: The results of Poland's parliamentary elections held on Oct. 15, 2023, have been lauded as a blow against populism—and they may also hold important lessons for reversing democracy's decline.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Language induces an identity crisis for the children and grandchildren of Latino immigrants
description: A young Latina mother I was interviewing once laughed uncomfortably as she described her sons' embarrassment when put on the spot by older Latinos.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Farming tuna on land heralded as a win for sustainability, but there are serious concerns about animal welfare
description: Atlantic bluefin tuna used to be caught only relatively rarely, mainly by sports fishermen in North America. But this all changed in the 1950s when consumers of sushi, particularly in Japan, developed more of a taste for the species.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Great Fire of London: How researchers uncovered the man who first found the flames
description: If you had been in London on September 2, 1666, the chances are you'd remember exactly where you were and who you were with. This was the day the Great Fire began, sweeping across the city for almost five days.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Queensland's fires are not easing at night. That's a bad sign for the summer ahead
description: This week, dozens of fires have burned across Queensland. More homes have burned in the state than during the 2019–2020 Black Summer—57 so far this year, compared to 49.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Using social media for your holiday 'inspo' can be risky and even dangerous—here's why
description: How do you choose your next travel destination? Social media platforms like Instagram and TikTok are handy tools for holiday research, full of 'inspo' for new and beautiful places to go.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Why women and minority groups are still underrepresented in top management
description: Over the past few years, there has been a great deal of research looking at how well women are represented in top companies. The findings continue to be distressing.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How is decaf coffee made? And is it really caffeine-free?
description: Coffee is one of the most popular drinks in the world, and its high levels of caffeine are among the main reasons why. It's a natural stimulant that provides an energy buzz, and we just can't get enough.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Micro heat engine research cracks an age-old thermodynamic puzzle
description: Designing a heat engine that can produce maximum power at maximum efficiency is a major challenge. Practical heat engines are limited to a theoretical efficiency called the Carnot limit, which sets a cap on how much heat can be converted to useful work.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Earth's vital signs are now in 'uncharted territory,' climate scientists warn
description: Massive wildfires in Canada, Greece and Hawaii. All-time record heat waves. Hurricanes with surprising ferocity, like the one that devastated Acapulco last week.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study reveals the origin of high superconducting critical temperatures in trilayer cuprates
description: High-temperature cuprate superconductors are a broad class of materials that exhibit some unique characteristics. Due to their distinctive properties, these materials exhibit the highest superconducting temperatures reported to date under ambient pressure.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Human emissions have increased mercury in the atmosphere sevenfold: Study
description: Humans have increased the concentration of potentially toxic mercury in the atmosphere sevenfold since the beginning of the modern era around 1500 C.E., according to new research from the Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (SEAS).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Space Force to split 21 launches between SpaceX, United Launch Alliance
description: The Space Force is giving a nearly even share of 21 upcoming national security launches between SpaceX and United Launch Alliance.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Chemical process makes peptide acquire structure similar to amyloid plaques found in neurodegenerative diseases
description: Peptides are biomolecules formed when two or more amino acids that perform key functions in the human organism, such as hormones, neurotransmitters, painkillers and antibiotics, bind together. For this reason, they are much studied and used by the pharmaceutical industry, for example.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Tree-regeneration decline and type-conversion after high-severity fires likely to cause little forest loss
description: Are western U.S. forests threatened so much by failing post-fire tree regeneration that extensive forest loss may occur by mid-century? Increasing temperatures are drying forests, more fires are being ignited, and they are increasingly burning at high severity, killing 70% or more of trees. High-severity fires leave behind post-fire openings that climate change is making hotter and drier; these spaces are often dominated by competitive shrubs and have substantial area that is distant from surviving trees that provide essential seed for tree regeneration.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New insights into the India–Asia collision in the Western Himalayas dating back to circa 55 million years
description: Hundreds of millions of years ago, the surface of the Earth looked very different from how we see it today. There were just two continents: Laurasia and Gondwanaland. The present Indian subcontinent was part of Gondwanaland, which broke up about 150 million years ago.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Workplace discrimination saps everyone's motivation, even if it works in your favor
description: When people work for discriminatory managers, they put in less effort. That's true both when managers are biased against them and when they're biased in their favor, according to a new paper that Nicholas Heiserman of Oklahoma State University and I have published in the journal Nature Human Behaviour.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New study shows how the Ebola virus infects cells
description: In a recent study published in Nature Communications, researchers from Karolinska Institutet and the Institute of Molecular Biotechnology have identified a new molecule in cells that is necessary for Ebola and Marburg viruses to infect and spread in the body.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Strange magnetic material could make computing energy-efficient
description: A research collaboration co-led by EPFL has uncovered a surprising magnetic property of an exotic material that might lead to computers that need less than one-millionth of the energy required to switch a single bit.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Neutralizing electronic inhomogeneity in cleaved bulk MoS₂
description: Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is a highly versatile material that can function, for example, as a gas sensor or as a photocatalyst in green hydrogen production. Although the understanding of a material usually starts from investigating its bulk crystalline form, for MoS2 much more studies have been devoted to mono and few layer nanosheets.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Ancient hyena droppings reveal genome of Ice Age woolly rhino
description: A team of paleontologists, evolutionists and geoscientists affiliated with several entities in Germany has extracted Ice Age woolly rhino DNA from fossilized excrement samples (coprolites) found in a cave in Germany. Their study is reported in the journal Biology Letters.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Two species of large ancient lampreys found in China
description: A trio of paleontologists, two with the Chinese Academy of Sciences and the third with Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle, UMR, has found the fossilized remains of two large lamprey species from the Jurassic in northeast China. In their paper published in the journal Nature Communications, Feixiang Wu, Philippe Janvier and Chi Zhang describe the site where the fossils were found, their condition, and features of the ancient lampreys.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Sperm can adjust their swimming style to adapt to fluctuating fluid conditions
description: Sperm can modulate their energetics by regulating their flagellar waveform—how the sperm oscillate their tails—in order to adapt to varying fluid environments, potentially optimizing their motility and navigation within the reproductive tract. This research is reported in a study published November 1 in the journal Cell Reports Physical Science.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Review explores biofabrication strategies with single-cell resolution
description: The recent advances in biofabrication with extremely high resolution (e.g. at the single-cell level) have greatly enhanced the capacity of biofabrication and opened new avenues for tissue engineering.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Bioprospecting the unknown: How bacterial enzymes encoded by unknown genes might help clean up pollution
description: Enzymes are biological nanomachines. They make almost all of life's chemistry happen, when and where required. Because of their versatility and power, enzymes can be very useful for biotechnology. Taken outside of living cells, they can be used to synthesize or modify pharmaceuticals or to degrade potential pollutants.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A liquid water-molecule-based graphene heterogeneous photodetector and its application in an oximeter
description: In the context of the development of smart health care towards digitalization, the new generation of photodetectors has a wide range of application prospects and huge market value. The characteristics of graphene material, such as large carrier mobility, excellent optical transparency and high mechanical strength, make it a favorite for the development of new generation photodetectors.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New flood modeling research aims to produce more accurate predictions
description: On Aug. 21, 2021, Waverly, Tennessee, received nearly one-third of its average annual rainfall in just a few hours—the resulting 17 inches of rain led to one of the deadliest flooding events on record.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New antimicrobial molecule shuts down bacterial growth without harming human cells
description: Scientists have shown how a molecule with broad-spectrum antibiotic activity works by disabling a process vital to bacterial growth without affecting the normal functioning of human cells. The journal mBio published the work, led by researchers at Emory University and Pennsylvania State University.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Plastic-eating bacteria turn waste into useful starting materials for other products
description: Mountains of used plastic bottles get thrown away every day, but microbes could potentially tackle this problem. Now, researchers report in ACS Central Science  that they've developed a plastic-eating E. coli that can efficiently turn polyethylene terephthalate (PET) waste into adipic acid, which is used to make nylon materials, drugs and fragrances.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New study finds that being alone does not closely correlate with feelings of loneliness
description: In a world filled with endless connections and constant communication, the relationship between loneliness and aloneness is not always clear. Now, University of Arizona researchers have analyzed that relationship—and found that they are two different things that are not closely correlated.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Simulating how electrons move through biological nanowires
description: The movement of electrons across wires is what allows us to use electricity every day. Biological nanowires, microscopic wires made of proteins, have caught researchers' attention for their ability to carry electrons over long distances.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Astronomers now know how far the Earth is from 200 galaxies
description: On July 11, 2022, the very first image taken by the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) was released to the general public. It's called Webb's First Deep Field, centered on a cluster of galaxies named SMACS 0723 and containing no less than 7,000 galaxies.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study shows marine oxygen landscape was shaped by plate movement and biological innovation
description: The oxygen content of seawater has a profound impact on the cycling of bioessential elements and the habitability of Earth. But how and why the marine oxygen landscape (i.e., the spatial pattern of oxygen levels) evolved since the start of the Phanerozoic 538 million years ago is not well established.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study offers new method for predicting drug-protein binding affinity
description: Accurately predicting the drug-protein interaction (DPI) is crucial in virtual drug screening. However, current methodologies tend to allocate equal weighting to amino acids and atoms in encoding protein and drug sequences, thereby neglecting the varying contributions from distinct motifs.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Ocean warming is accelerating, and hotspots reveal which areas are absorbing the most heat
description: Ocean warming has accelerated dramatically since the 1990s, nearly doubling during 2010–2020 relative to 1990–2000, according to new UNSW Sydney-led research.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Eruption of Eurasia's tallest active volcano sends ash columns above a Russian peninsula
description: Huge ash columns erupted from Eurasia's tallest active volcano Wednesday, forcing authorities to close schools in two towns on Russia's sparsely populated Kamchatka Peninsula.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: China's smog problem explained
description: A thick haze has this week smothered Beijing and surrounding areas, with tens of millions of people in northern China under severe pollution warnings.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Nanowire 'brain' network learns and remembers 'on the fly'
description: For the first time, a physical neural network has successfully been shown to learn and remember "on the fly," in a way inspired by and similar to how the brain's neurons work.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: China lithium boom harming fragile Tibetan plateau: report
description: China's booming electric vehicle industry is fueling a lithium rush in the Tibetan plateau that risks damaging the troubled region's fragile ecology and deepening rights violations, research published Wednesday said.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Targets to end fossil fuel at COP28 crucial: EU climate chief
description: A demand for targets for the phase-out of fossil fuels in the final agreement of COP28 in Dubai is not frivolous but an urgent request backed by "crystal clear" science, Europe's climate commissioner told AFP on Tuesday.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Storms swell Iguazu falls to near decade-high flow
description: Heavy rains have swollen the famed Iguazu waterfalls on the border between Argentina and Brazil to near decade-high water volumes this week, authorities said, as flooding engulfed one of the site's main tourist walkways.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Europe's economic powerhouse tests a shorter working week
description: Maximilian Hermann's weekend starts on Friday morning, when he puts his motorcycle helmet on and takes his bike out for a ride to the southern German Alps.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: In Brazil town turning to desert, farmers fight to hang on
description: Standing amid a terrain of rugged red craters that looks like something from Mars, Brazilian farmer Ubiratan Lemos Abade extends his arms, pointing to two possible futures for this land fast turning to desert.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: North China smog to last until mid-November: state media
description: Serious pollution is expected to remain over Beijing and surrounding areas until the middle of the month, Chinese state media said Wednesday.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
